Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Photomodulation of Forster Cycle in a Fluorescent Protein

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Kalkan, Kaan
Proposal No.: 1512157

This project seeks to develop new types of optical probes that are faster and more efficient at switching, while reducing effects of photobleaching. They will study the photophysics of energy transfer between metal nanoparticles and fluorescent proteins to develop stable photoactivatable probes for super-resolution microscopy applications.

The hypothesized photoswitching is based on photocreation of the intermediate state in the Forster cycle of the FP using surface-enhanced optical pumping. This photomodulation of the Forster cycle will be verified and studied by single molecule surface-enhanced Raman scattering and micro-optical spectroscopy. This effort will develop a photoswitch using Green Fluorescent Protein (GFP) - silver NP conjugates as its prototype. The photomodulation is based upon photopopulation of the intermediate form (I-form) of GFP by excited state proton transfer that red-shifts the optical absorption from 395 to 490 nm. This spectral shift in absorption, in turn, is expected to modulate the Mie scattering of the plasmonic NP by resonant energy transfer to the FP.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Super-resolution optical microscopy won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2014. This advance exploits blinking fluorescent molecules and allows for imaging of the tiny organelles in a cell with a light microscope (e.g., gets around the diffraction limit of light). Researchers need brighter and faster switching blinkers to best utilize this technique. In this project, we have conjugated the green fluorescent protein (GFP), found in jellyfish, with a silver nanoparticle to develop such a switchable light emitter. Light scattered from plasmonic metal nanoparticles can be thousands of times brighter and more stable than that emitted from fluorescent molecules.

Our objective has been to turn this emission on and off (blink) using the energy transfer mechanism in a protein-nanoparticle conjugate. This approach relies on combination of the rich photophysics in GFP, mainly the Forster cycle, and its strong electromagnetic coupling with a plasmonic nanoparticle. By the end of the second year of the project, we have established turning on/off the scattered light from a single silver nanoparticle, conjugated with GFP.

Additionally, we have developed a novel nanoparticle biofunctionalization protocol and used it to internalize 100-nm-size silver nanoparticles into live cells. Currently, we are employing this technique to tag the nanoparticles specifically to the cytoskeleton and image it.

During the final year of the present project, the PI turned back to his single-molecule vibrational spectroscopy (surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS)) work in elucidation of the dark state(s) of GFP, the protein molecule for which the blinking was observed for the first time.

This single-molecule vibrational spectroscopy effort, combined with density functional theory (DFT) computations, have revealed the presence of a twisted nonplanar conformation for the chromophore of GFP. This conformation is likely the dark state of GFP, being responsible for its fluorescence blinking. As in the cis (planar) conformation, a proton wire is found to be instrumental in the nonplanar conformation, which is between the phenol oxygen of the chromophore and carboxyl of Glu222. Thereby, the nonplanar chromophore can protonate and deprotonate just like its planar form.
